pitrou opened a new pull request #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674
 
 
   The main perk of using Azure Pipelines currently is that it gives 10 parallel jobs for open source projects, which is much higher than what AppVeyor offers.

pitrou commented on issue #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-425970143
 
 
   Thank you @kaylangan. One thing that came up was whether it's possible to speed up C++/CMake builds with a compilation cache, like [clcache](https://github.com/frerich/clcache). Another is to have pre-compiled Boost builds (both Debug and Release) on the hosted VS images.
   
   A specific pain point was that the system drive (C:) seems quite slow, which led me to override the default location for various things (such as Conda package downloads and Conda environments).

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

vtbassmatt commented on issue #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-426621615
 
 
   Hey folks, like @kaylangan I'm a PM on Azure Pipelines. I know woefully little about C++, having not touched it since undergrad, so bear with some dumb questions. Will you see speedups from clcache within a single build job, or does it only help if you can cache across runs? We don't offer any persistent storage between runs in the hosted pools.
   
   We can definitely investigate having precompiled Boost available. I've opened a feature request to have a C++ expert investigate: https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-image-generation/issues/263
   
   Performance characteristics of C: vs D: using Azure VMs the way we do is... complicated :) If you're finding that for your workloads, the D: drive is faster, then you should use it. (That's likewise why we run the agent itself off the D: drive.) We don't make D: the default for a lot of things due to space constraints.

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

pitrou commented on issue #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-426710948
 
 
   > Will you see speedups from clcache within a single build job, or does it only help if you can cache across runs? We don't offer any persistent storage between runs in the hosted pools.
   
   It would only help accross runs. We do this on AppVeyor, and it helps mildly (depending on which parts of the source code have changed).

   Oh, right now things seem definitely better than on AppVeyor. No doubt about it.
   
   The caching point is a more general point that I know many people try to set up on their CI configuration, regardless of the provider (AppVeyor, Travis...), because it's a way to save some minutes here and there, therefore it helps reduce latencies and development turnaround when testing things on CI.

   Glad to hear you're having a good experience!
   
   With our current architecture (we throw away the VM after every run), adding caching is pretty challenging. But it's definitely a common request, and we have a few ideas to run down.

pitrou commented on issue #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-431100206
 
 
   @vtbassmatt @kaylangan The Apache Foundation can't allow Azure Pipelines to be enabled on the Apache Arrow repository, as the AP app requires to give write access to the repository. Is there anything you could do to remove that requirement?

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

vtbassmatt commented on issue #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-431125975
 
 
   Write access is required to set up the web hooks and GitHub Checks. It also sets things up in an application identity instead of someone's personal GitHub identity.
   
   If you're interested in trying things out without web hooks, you'll have to manually queue builds - no PR or CI integration. Also, GitHub Checks won't be set up. Mostly pointing that out so that when others come along, they'll understand why those features aren't lit up. Here are the steps:
   1. Go to your Azure Pipelines organization
   2. Choose "New pipeline"
   3. Choose the option to "use the visual designer" instead of choosing GitHub at the top
   4. Go through our older, wizard-based experience, using an OAuth connection under your own GitHub credentials
   5. Before you save the pipeline, make sure to go to the Triggers tab and turn off CI/PR builds -- if those are "on" and you don't have the right to create webhooks, we will fail to save the build.
   6. Save the pipeline and manually queue.

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

   Curious: what would it take to get the right permissions? I noticed after I posted that AppVeyor's rich integration _is_ installed, so there must be a path to getting write access.

   @vtbassmatt This is what Appveyor asks for:
   
   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/183673/47804657-a79eaf80-dd35-11e8-8435-1d09da68149f.png)
   https://github.com/settings/connections/applications/01881570529737c25f97

   So seems they are doing things without write access. (Note that theses are OAuth apps in Github, not GitHub/Marketplace apps. Their GitHub app is pretty new: https://www.appveyor.com/blog/2018/10/02/github-apps-integration/)

janpio commented on issue #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-434773392
 
 
   I tried to follow your steps @vtbassmatt to get it working via your old flow with OAuth. 
   
   1. I could only select an apache repo when I used the "personal access token" method, not the "OAuth" or "Grant authorization" as the apache org did not allow this I think. Did I mess up or was this information missing from your list above?
   
   2. I created a pipeline for one of "my" repos: https://dev.azure.com/apache-cordova/cordova-lib/_build But I couldn't figure out how to configure it to use the configuration file from the PR: https://github.com/apache/cordova-lib/pull/696 What do I have to do so it uses the `azure-pipelines.yml`?
   
   3. Also, did I get the limitations of this method right?
   
   - No automatic builds on PRs and commits - each and every build has to be manually triggered via the web UI.
   - No check integration into PRs that could report the build state back to GitHub - all feedback is in the Azure Pipelines UI only.

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-434774531
 
 
   Any one last reply to @vtbassmatt :
   
   > Curious: what would it take to get the right permissions?
   
   From my understanding only committers with the correct paperwork submitted to Apache may have write access to the _code_. So any GitHub app (or app in general) that can change code but does so in its own name, will not work. Does Azure Pipelines _really_ have to be able to modify the _code_? Could there be other ways to achieve the necessary configuration? 
   
   I am always confused about the permissions of apps, but afaik this is mostly because the permissions are not granular enough. Does this apply here? Could GitHub change something to fix this?

----------------------------------------------------------------

vtbassmatt commented on issue #2674: [EXP] ARROW-3253: [CI] Set up CI with Azure Pipelines [skip travis]
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2674#issuecomment-435069822
 
 
   Hi, sorry for my delay in responding!
   
   We're investigating whether we can still give the rich experience we want to give without forcing write access. (Ideally, GitHub would give us a way to *request* write access but gracefully degrade if the user declines. That doesn't exist yet.) Things look promising here but I don't have an ETA.
   
   On the PAT vs OAuth question -- I may be missing a nuance of our system there. @DavidStaheli can you weigh in?
   
   And on the limitations -- when I wrote that, I forgot that we could fall back to service hooks. You'll get the automatic builds of PRs and so on, but you won't get the GitHub Checks integration. When you create a pipeline using OAuth (and I would think PAT as well), we should set those webhooks up automatically. I'll shoot you a mail so we can troubleshoot why that's not working for you.

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

fields.description:
C++ builds on AppVeyor have become slower and slower. Some of it may be due to the parquet-cpp repository merge, but I also suspect CPU resources on AppVeyor have become much tighter.

We should perhaps investigate Microsoft's Azure CI services as an alternative:
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-gb/services/devops/pipelines/

comments.body:
I suggest splitting the C++ unit tests into a separate build from the Python unit tests as one way to speed things up. The build times aren't _too_ bad though yet:

https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/arrow/build/1.0.7968

It seems the C++ build phase is ballooning. See here, 19 minutes to end up with a compilation failure (no unittest executed):
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/pitrou/arrow/build/1.0.732

Ouch. That build has some other problems -- it's building Thrift from source which is really slow:

{code}
-- THRIFT_HOME: 
-- Thrift compiler/libraries NOT found:  (THRIFT_INCLUDE_DIR-NOTFOUND, THRIFT_STATIC_LIB-NOTFOUND). Looked in system search paths.
-- Thrift include dir: C:/projects/arrow/cpp/build/thrift_ep/src/thrift_ep-install/include
-- Thrift static library: C:/projects/arrow/cpp/build/thrift_ep/src/thrift_ep-install/lib/thriftmd.lib
-- Thrift compiler: C:/projects/arrow/cpp/build/thrift_ep/src/thrift_ep-install/bin/thrift
-- Thrift version: 0.11.0
{code}

I think our CI should just use the toolchain always for performance and we should move our "thirdparty testing" to a Crossbow job, so we can verify nightly or on demand that all the projects will build automatically from source
Ironically the toolchain is also rather slow to fetch... at least when using conda-forge.
It might be a dark path, but we could look at snapshotting the conda packages and putting it in a CDN
Anaconda is already backed by a CDN, I think. So perhaps we can ditch just use of conda-forge (which also makes conda dependency resolution faster)?
Does Anaconda have all the Windows build deps? That would be OK with me if that works

By the way, it seems that creating both shared and static Arrow libraries compiles the C++ files twice. See e.g. https://ci.appveyor.com/project/pitrou/arrow/build/1.0.735/job/0c2taiirl0srwyw0?fullLog=true and look for "key_value_metadata.cc".

Ideally we should be able to only build the shared libraries on Windows, but it seems there are linking problems in some places...
Opened ARROW-3268 about the conda times issue.
Some of the unit tests depend on the static libraries, I think that's the issue.

Initial toying with Azure pipelines is killing my hopes, since a simple "conda update conda" seems to be taking 2 minutes alone:
https://dev.azure.com/pitrou/arrow/_build/results?buildId=12&view=logs

I wonder if CPython has a special plan with larger dedicated resources.
I asked and got the answer: the C: drive is slow on Azure Pipeline, the D: drive must be used for conda environments and package cache.

pandas has just set up azure pipelines, if there is anything to learn:

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/azure-pipelines.yml

Got a release build to work here, with toolchain packages:
https://dev.azure.com/pitrou/arrow/_build/results?buildId=49&view=logs

I also disabled optimizations in the release build, which should help AppVeyor builds too.
INFRA ticket for Azure Pipelines already exists at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-17030
Considering INFRA's response at INFRA-17030, bailing out.
